floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim
River Stour, River Lodden, River Shreen

items.message: River levels remain high after yesterday's rain in the Gillingham Le Neubourg Way area. Consequently, their is still  a risk of localised flooding. We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton.  River levels can rise very quickly in response to heavy rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 18/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels continue to fall at the Lilbourne river gauge after persistent heavy rainfall on Tueday, 16/03/2022. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible today, 18/03/2022. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to continue falling today, 18/03/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 18/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Leicestershire, Lincolnshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, Rutland, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the Welland Valley. This means that the River Welland and River Jordan rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected.  However, river levels will remain high over the next few days.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the South Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham and its tributaries rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected and we expect to remove this flood alert tomorrow.  However, river levels will remain high over the next 24 hours.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of Wednesday's heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into the evening, 18/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 18/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.message: Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the River Welland catchment. This means that the Welland tributaries rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected.  However, whilst most river levels are falling, Eye Brook is still rising and will remain high over the next few days.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the Harpers Brook and Willow Brook area. This means that these rivers rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected and we expect to remove this flood alert tomorrow.  However, river levels will remain high over the next 24 hours.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bradford on Avon gauge at Bradford on Avon  as a result of heavy rainfall, with over 15 mm of rain fallen in the last 24 hours. River levels on the River Avon at Great Somerford, River Avon at Bradford on Avon, River Avon at Bathford and Semington Brook at Semington are rising through this evening (the 16th March 2022). Currently we are not forecasting flood warning thresholds to be met. 

This message will be updated on Friday the 18th March 2022, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to effect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. We are closely monitoring the situation.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Cappenham river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding has reduced along the River Tove.  
Drier, brighter conditions are forecast for Friday and Saturday.

items.description: Minor watercourses of the South Forty Foot Drain
items.message: Yesterday, Wednesday, 16th March, heavy rain fell in the minor watercourses of South Forty Foot Drain catchment area. This means that the rivers rose over the last 24 hours. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecast has improved and no further flooding is expected, however, some river levels will remain high. We expect to remove this flood alert in the next 48 hours. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the River Blackwater is now falling. As high pressure builds, the weather is now mostly dry for the next five days. This will allow the river plenty of chance to recover, returning to a more normal level by tomorrow (18/03/2022). We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

River levels are now falling at the Eathopre gauge following heavy rainfall Tuesday, 16/03/2022. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 18/03/22. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to continue falling today, 18/03/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 18/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the North Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham and its tributaries are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from the morning of Thursday 17th March onwards. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Ise and Alledge Brook catchment area. This means that the River Ise and Alledge Brook are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to these rivers from the morning of Thursday, 17th March onwards. We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for  blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Friday, 18th March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are continuing to fall at the Brackley river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding has reduced along the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook.
   
Drier, brighter conditions are forecast for Friday and Saturday.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. The forecast is for a dry day tomorrow (18/03/22) and into the weekend. 
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Thame as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land possible overnight tonight (17/3/22) especially around Thame Bridge, Stadhampton and Dorchester. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning, 18/03/22, or as the situation changes. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

River levels have risen at the Hammoon river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday afternoon. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from now until 10:00 tomorrow, Friday the 17/03/22.  We expect flooding to affect West Street, Shorts Lane, Barnack Walk, Market Place, Sheep Market Hill, East Street, Nightingale Court, Damory Street, River Mews and Langton Road in Blandford   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until 12:00 on 17/03/22
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels are continuing to fall at the Wimpole river gauge. 
Consequently, the risk of flooding has reduced along the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield.   
  
Drier, brighter conditions are forecast for Friday and Saturday.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thames and small tributaries as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and land is possible later this evening 17/03/22, especially between Hannington Bridge and Lechlade. 
We expect river levels to remain high overnight in tomorrow (18/3/22).
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning, 18/3/22, or as the situation changes.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Ray as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and land is possible this evening 17/03/22, especially in the Islip area. 
 We expect river levels to remain high overnight and tomorrow 18/03/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Frisby river gauge as a result of Wednesday's heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding to roads and farmland remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including at Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe, Syston, Melton, Asfordby including Station Lane and Ratcliffe on the Wreake including Broome Lane. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until this evening, 18/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 18/03/22, or as the situation changes.
